hierarchy.title: Heading Hierarchy
hierarchy.noHeadingsFound: No headings found on this page.

criticalIssues.title: Critical Issues
criticalIssues.levelSkip: Level skip: Heading levels should not skip
criticalIssues.empty: Empty: Heading has no text content
criticalIssues.multipleH1: Multiple H1: Only one H1 per page recommended
criticalIssues.missingH1: Missing H1: Page should have exactly one H1

warnings.title: Warnings
warnings.tooShort: Too short: Very short heading text
warnings.tooLong: Too long: Very long heading text

infoModal.title: Understanding Heading Issues
infoModal.subtitle: Learn about heading structure issues and how to fix them

colorGuide.title: Color Guide
colorGuide.redDescription: Critical errors that must be fixed (affects SEO and accessibility)
colorGuide.orangeDescription: Warnings that should be reviewed (best practice issues)

empty.title: Empty Heading
empty.description: A heading tag exists but contains no text content. This provides no value to users or search engines.
empty.fix: Add descriptive text to the heading or remove the empty tag entirely.

short.title: Short Heading (< 10 characters)
short.description: Heading text is too short to be descriptive. While not always wrong, very short headings may lack context.
short.fix: Consider adding more descriptive text to clearly communicate the section's content.

long.title: Long Heading (> 70 characters)
long.description: Heading text is very long. This can be hard to scan and may indicate the content should be split.
long.fix: Break down into shorter, more scannable headings or move extra detail into paragraph text.

skip.title: Skipped Heading Level
skip.description: Heading levels should follow sequential order (H1 → H2 → H3). Skipping levels (e.g., H1 → H3) breaks the document outline and confuses screen readers.
skip.fix: Adjust heading levels to follow proper hierarchy. Don't skip from H1 directly to H3 without an H2 in between.

orphan.title: Orphaned Heading
orphan.description: A heading appears before the H1 tag or without a proper parent in the hierarchy. This breaks the document outline that search engines use to understand your page structure.
orphan.fix: For headings appearing before H1: Convert them to non-heading elements like <div>, <p>, or <span> and apply CSS classes to maintain styling. For headings without proper parents: Ensure H2s are under H1, H3s under H2, etc.

solution.title: SEO Solution
solution.description: These headings appear before your H1 and break the document outline. For better SEO, convert them to non-heading elements:
solution.stylingNote: Keep the styling: Apply CSS classes to maintain the visual appearance.

multipleH1.title: Multiple H1 Tags
multipleH1.description: Multiple H1 tags were found on the page. While technically valid in HTML5, having one H1 per page is an SEO best practice.
multipleH1.fix: Use only one H1 tag for the main page title. Convert additional H1s to H2 or other appropriate levels.

bestPractices.title: Best Practices
bestPractices.item1: Use only one H1 per page (typically the page title or main heading)
bestPractices.item2: Follow sequential heading levels (H1 → H2 → H3, don't skip)
bestPractices.item3: Make headings descriptive and meaningful (10-70 characters is ideal)
bestPractices.item4: Use headings to create a logical document outline for both users and search engines
